message_1:
Find the Laurent series expansion of the function 

f(z) = ln(z) 

centered at 

z0 = 1 

that converges in the annulus 

1/2 < |z-1| < 3/2.
message_2:
To find the Laurent series expansion of f(z) = ln(z) centered at z0 = 1, we first rewrite the function in terms of (z-1). Since ln(z) = ln(1 + (z-1)), we can use the natural logarithm power series expansion:

ln(1 + x) = x - x^2/2 + x^3/3 - x^4/4 + ...

Now, we substitute x = (z-1) to get the Laurent series expansion of f(z) centered at z0 = 1:

f(z) = (z-1) - (z-1)^2/2 + (z-1)^3/3 - (z-1)^4/4 + ...

This series converges in the annulus 1/2 < |z-1| < 3/2.
